required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Bone Metabolic Activity in the Patellofemoral Joint in Patients With Unilateral PFP
clinical_study.official_title: Study of Subchondral Bone Remodeling With 18F NaF-PET / CT in Patients With Patellofemoral Pain. A Substudy for: Comparative Effectiveness of Therapeutic Hip and Knee Exercise for Patellofemoral Pain: a Pragmatic Randomised Trial (the COMPETE Trial)

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to examine whether individuals with unilateral patellofemoral pain (PFP) have increased subchondral bone remodelling and thus increased 18F Sodium Fluoride (18F-NaF) uptake in the painful knee compared to the opposite knee measured by simultaneous positron emission tomography and computed tomography (PET/CT) and to examine whether the increased uptake is associated with pain intensity, with patient-reported function and with pain localization. Furthermore we aim to investigate the effect of an acute patellofemoral loading bout and 12 weeks of resistance training on bone activity.

study_design_info.masking_description: Investigator and outcome assessor will remain unaware of treatment group. Physiotherapists involved in exercise instruction will not be blinded. Nor will the participants.

primary_outcome.description: Difference between painful knee and contralateral knee in mean and peak standardized uptake value (SUV).

secondary_outcome.description: Change in mean and peak SUV from baseline to 12 weeks follow-up

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed before and after acute loading programme at baseline (day 0)
secondary_outcome.description: Response to acute patellofemoral joint loading in mean and peak SUV
Change in the response to acute patellofemoral joint loading in mean and peak SUV from baseline to 12 weeks follow-up

secondary_outcome.measure: 18F NaF-PET/CT uptake and pain intensity, pain localization and physical function.
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between tracer uptake and pain intensity measured by pain algometry, pain localization measured by pain drawings and physical function measured by the Anterior Knee Pain Scale

other_outcome.time_frame: Cross sectional assessment at baseline (day 0) and changes assessed prospectively 0-12 weeks
other_outcome.description: Presence of micro-structural changes in subchondral bone measured by cone beam CT
Correlation between micro-structural changes in subchondral bone measured by cone beam CT and 18F NaF-PET/CT uptake

arm_group.description: 12 weeks of strength training focusing on the knee mobilising muscles including squat, lunge and knee extension exercises.
12 weeks of strength training focusing on the hip stabilising muscles including sidelying and standing hip abduction, clam and hip extension exercises.

intervention.intervention_name: 18F NaF-PET/CT and cone beam CT scans
intervention.description: Cross sectional and prospective measures of 18F NaF-PET/CT and cone beam CT scans before and after a 12 weeks training period

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- A clinical diagnosis of PFP in at least one knee confirmed by an experienced sports medicine doctor.
- Visual analogue score rating of pain during activities of daily living during the previous week at a minimum of 3 on a 10 cm scale.
- Insidious onset of symptoms unrelated to trauma and persistent for at least 4 weeks.
- Pain in the anterior knee associated with at least 3 of the following:
- During or after activity
- Prolonged sitting
- Stair ascent or descent
- Squatting
Exclusion Criteria:
- Meniscal or other intra-articular injury
- Cruciate or collateral ligament laxity or tenderness
- Patellar tendon, iliotibial band, or pes anserine tenderness
- Osgood-Schlatter or Sinding-Larsen-Johansson syndrome
- History of recurrent patellar subluxation or dislocation
- History of surgery to the knee joint
- History of head injury or vestibular disorder within the last 6 months
- Pregnancy
- Breastfeeding
